metadata.notes: Delivered on the Second Sunday in Lent, 2000. Context involves the rise of the 'Jesus Seminar' and historical-critical skepticism.

freedom_from_critical_parent_CP.score_explanation: 10 = Completely free from coercive judgments. 0 = Very dominant Critical Parent.
freedom_from_critical_parent_CP.analysis: The preacher uses a strong CP voice to warn against 'insidious developments' and 'adulterous generations.' The tone is one of dogmatic defense against intellectual 'iconoclasts.'
quotes: Whoever is ashamed of me... of him will the Son of man also be ashamed
Being ashamed of Jesus means being robbed of the everlasting arm of God

healthy_care_NP.score_explanation: 10 = Healthy, non-smothering care. 0 = Absent or smothering.
healthy_care_NP.analysis: Care is present but conditional upon accepting the 'traditional affirmation.' It offers comfort (NP) only after establishing a threat (CP).
quotes: The passage is not an expression of religious optimism... The passage depends for its truth on who Jesus is.

adult.analysis: The preacher engages in intellectual debate and cites scholars, addressing the listener's intellect. However, the Adult is often bypassed by an appeal to fear (Child) or dogma (Parent).
quotes: Iâ€™ll be the first to admit that we can no longer read ancient texts as innocently as our forebears did.
There are various criticisms that can be made of this procedure.

freedom_from_adapted_child_AC.score_explanation: 10 = Free from fear/compliance. 0 = Strong Adapted Child (fear culture).
freedom_from_adapted_child_AC.analysis: The sermon heavily leverages the Adapted Child's fear of rejection ('the Son of man will be ashamed of him'). It demands compliance to a specific creedal formula to avoid abandonment.
quotes: In spite of the very serious doubts that frequently assail me...
Being ashamed of Jesus means that the Son of God will fade from your view.

free_child_FC.analysis: There is very little spontaneity or joy; the atmosphere is one of 'tumultuous struggle' and 'defiant notes.'

transaction_analysis.analysis: The preacher speaks as a guardian of orthodoxy (Parent) to a congregation potentially 'bewitched' or 'confused' (Child).
transaction_analysis.ulterior_motives: Socially, it is an Adult-Adult theological lecture. Psychologically, it is a Parent-Child warning: 'If you doubt, you will be abandoned by God.'
transaction_analysis.risk_explanation: The 'double bottom' lies in the definition of 'shame.' It equates intellectual questioning (Adult) with moral failure/shame (Child), creating a psychological trap.

detected_games.name: Bait & Switch (Redemption)

formula_g_analysis.con: Promise of 'the love of God' from which nothing can separate us.
formula_g_analysis.gimmick: The listener's fear of suffering and the 'darkest hour.'
formula_g_analysis.switch: The love is conditional on not being 'ashamed' (doubting the traditional view).
formula_g_analysis.payoff: The listener feels guilty for their doubts and clings more tightly to the preacher's dogma.

evidence_quotes: If Paul is not telling the truth, then there is something that can separate us... and that is ourselves.

detected_games.name: Ain't It Awful

formula_g_analysis.con: Identifying a common enemy (the Jesus Seminar/scholars).
formula_g_analysis.gimmick: The congregation's sense of being 'under assault.'
formula_g_analysis.switch: Moving from 'they are attacking us' to 'you might be one of them.'
formula_g_analysis.payoff: A sense of righteous isolation and collective anxiety.

evidence_quotes: The more insidious developments are occurring without our noticing...
Throughout the mainline denominations, many clergy are dodging and backtracking.

preacher_roles.rescuer: Offers the 'ancient confession' as the only shield against despair.
preacher_roles.persecutor: Labels scholars as 'insidious' and warns that Jesus will be 'ashamed' of the doubters.
preacher_roles.victim: Portrays himself and the church as being under 'persistent assaults' and 'antagonism.'

drama_triangle_analysis.congregation_position: Victim (helpless against 'insidious' scholars, needing the preacher to rescue their faith).
drama_triangle_analysis.escape_possibilities: Low. The sermon discourages the Adult 'quest' and demands submission to the Spirit-led creed.

conclusion_and_recommendation.summary: The sermon is psychologically heavy, relying on a 'Fear of Abandonment' hook. While it purports to offer the security of God's love, it creates a 'double bind' where intellectual honesty (Adult) is framed as a spiritual betrayal (Child). The preacher's own admitted 'serious doubts' are used not to build Adult-Adult empathy, but to reinforce the necessity of a Parent-Child leap of faith.
strengths: High intellectual engagement with contemporary culture.
Vivid use of narrative (the couple with the suicidal son).
areas_for_improvement: Heavy reliance on Critical Parent 'musts' and 'shoulds'.
Framing doubt as 'shame' rather than an Adult processing of reality.
conclusion_and_recommendation.advice_for_game_free_communication: Try to speak more from the Adult ego state: acknowledge that faith and historical inquiry can coexist without the threat of divine 'shame.' Move away from the Drama Triangle by not casting scholars as 'insidious' villains.
